In what is good one should practice, seeing evil one should be like poison,
Therefore this heedlessness is said to be the first dangerous path.
Those beings who are heedless are deceived by beautiful words,
Always confused and intoxicated in their minds, suffering is only their share.
Not fearing suffering and distress, not seeking heavenly bliss,
Due to lacking wisdom and observation, they are no different from animals.
In food, drink, and sexual desire, their minds never let go for a moment,
Such beings are then the same as animals.
Those who delight in playing and amusing themselves dwell in Yama's mouth,
Death is then right before them, this suffering is difficult to endure.
Beings whose minds are heedless, who delight in destruction, die young,
Because of their heedlessness, they will eventually be ground to dust by death.
There is only one good dharma that brings peace and security to one's life,
And also gives rise to the various heavens, which is called heedfulness.
Heedlessness and heedfulness give rise to faults and merits,
Good and evil all arise from the mind, and so is liberation from bondage.
Sentient beings do not understand that happiness is like an enemy,
Their minds are extremely foolish, far from the wisdom of the Buddha.
Heedlessness is like a poisonous tree, with three trunks rising up,
Always relying on old age, sickness, and death to abide.
Those who fully cultivate right practice are not harmed by them,
The wise dwell in saá¹ƒsÄra, always delighting in heedfulness.
If one delights in heedfulness, one will be free from faults,

If one is endowed with heedlessness, I will then give rise to fear,

Due to craving, one gives rise to heedlessness, and will fall into the lotus hell,
There, in control of desire, one always abides within.
If one abides in heedlessness, four kinds of perversions arise,
Causing the destruction of good conduct, like worldly enmity.
Immeasurable doubts and fears always oppress,
Transmigrating in the cycle of birth and death, all due to heedless conduct.
This one heedless conduct, always delighting in various pleasures,
Then one is far removed from all, the pure dharmas free from outflows.
Because the gods are heedless, they go on and on without end,

Departing from defiled thoughts, the mind then becomes tranquil,
Able to benefit oneself and others, without further distress.
The gods are attached to the pleasures of desire, what have they ever seen?
This pleasure arises from conditioned existence, it is impermanent and does not last long.
This conditioned form, its characteristics are definitely destroyed,
When that pleasure is destroyed, then suffering and distress arise.
If a person is heedless and their mind is disturbed by the objects of desire,
There will definitely be separation, and later they will experience distress.
Regarding the five objects of desire, craving and attachment gain control,
Those desires deceive the gods, and heedlessness then follows.
If a person acts heedlessly, this is the root of all difficulties,
Regarding wealth, they give rise to greed and extensively create all that is unwholesome.
If a person in this life is endowed with all happiness,
They should follow the practice of wisdom, like a fish following the flowing water.
If the devas are negligent, they are subdued by the beauty of women,
Then they are burned by them, and always experience suffering and distress.
Therefore, the devas and humans should single-mindedly stay far away from [women],
Always be content with their minds, and not be bound by desire.
The foolish are confused about sin and merit, and do not know the Dharma and what is contrary to the Dharma,
This person cannot obtain even a little bit of nirvana.
With regard to the light and heavy precepts, and the profound essentials of the Dharma,
If one always delights in cultivating them, then one will attain that peace and joy.
Always delighting in proclaiming the true Dharma, and washing away all impurities,
Not engaging in negligent conduct, one will always attain wonderful joy.
In the past, delighting in negligent conduct, always confused and deluded,
Whether devas or worldly people, all should not associate with [such a one].
Creating the faults of negligence, never ceasing for a moment,
When their lives are about to end, they will go to the evil paths.
This is said to be their negligence, not in accord with principle,
The gods are always deluded and confused, and will fall into hell.
The gods are deluded by desire, loving what is unlovable,
Ignorant and unaware, how can they have any little happiness?
The gods always delight in and become attached to the five desires,
Like those born blind, they do not see the right path.
Because their minds are scattered, they do not give rise to true insight,
Negligence always burns, therefore one should stay far away from it.
The wholesome dharmas of the mind are destroyed by negligence,
The eightfold noble path is clearly seen, but ultimately cannot be seen.
This negligence is a poison that can destroy the ten wholesome dharmas,
In this way, the negligent one loses the four kinds of meditative absorption.
The buddhas are free from the five desires, and always praise non-negligence.
This body is invaded by old age and death, one should be disgusted and detached from negligence.
Negligence only has suffering, being detached from it is liberation.
Being dragged by negligence, the ignorant cannot cut it off.
Non-negligence is supreme, the gods like to be close to it.
If one acts negligently, one will certainly know to fall and perish.
All sentient beings revolve and do not attain liberation,
Because they are bound by the noose of negligence, it is difficult for them to escape.
Creating evil does not bring blessings, creating good does not invite sin.
The sentient beings who are negligent always give rise to inverted views,
How can one create blessings and virtues?
This is not what the world says.
The wise are well-aware and do not praise negligence.
If the gods are negligent, they will lose their good karma,
One should know that this evil cause will definitely lead to suffering as its result.
If the mind is attached to desires, giving rise to a little pleasure for a short time,
Then it will be destroyed by them, and upon losing it, great suffering will arise.
The objects of the senses are always present, but foolish people are never satisfied.
Confused and attached to women, one will then see their downfall.
Because of greed, one becomes negligent and associates with various women.

It is the cause for their downfall, and creates the basis for the suffering of hell.
It is shown that a single heedlessness is the cause for all suffering and distress,
If one delights in benefiting others, one always avoids that fault.
If one is free from heedlessness, one will reach the place of immortality,

If one delights in negligence, then one gives rise to that perversion,
And by such karmic fruits, one follows the flow of birth and death.
The blazing fire of that hell always burns the negligent person.
If one delights in liberation, then one abandons negligence.
If a person is free from negligence, then one gives rise to clear wisdom,
Permanently severing all afflictions, always experiencing that wonderful bliss.
Sentient beings' minds are scattered and bound by karma,
Transmigrating within the three existences, one should delight in being diligent.
Regarding suffering as happiness, happiness perishes and suffering arises.

Carelessness can give rise to craving, and from craving, anger arises again.
It is the source of all afflictions, and one sinks and transmigrates in the evil destinies.
The wise are not attached to either carelessness or carefulness,
This is the supreme peace and security, ascending to the tower of wisdom.
If one can leave carelessness and abide well in the blissful state,
One will become a great wise man and quickly realize the true and eternal fruit.

It can destroy the Dharma of liberation and give rise to all false thoughts,
Falling into those perilous and evil destinies, all arise from carelessness.
Not seeking one's own benefit, one is abandoned by others,
Without words and nothing to do, one is then like a dead person.
Although possessing the form of a celestial being, the fool is the same as the animals,
Always dwelling in heedlessness, they engage in singing, dancing, and jesting.
If a person is attached to heedlessness, they will enter the ocean of the three existences,

Because of this, they create various offenses, bound by their karma,
Heedlessness turns into an enemy, going against all wholesome dharmas.
This karma does not abide within, nor does it exist externally,
One should know that the heedless are all destroyed by the mind.
In the supreme realm, the mind is never satisfied,
Delighting in singing, dancing, and play, not knowing where they will fall and perish.
The foolish and heedless ones take fear as joy,
Those gods are born blind, not knowing the right path from the wrong path.
Because of their heedless conduct, they fall from the various meditations,

Beings deceived by greed, constantly burned by anger and hatred,
Subjugated by ignorance, they always praise desire.
Creating much evil karma, they obtain little taste of desire,
Because of indulging in greed and delusion, they do not understand suffering as suffering.

If one is able to leave behind those faults, then there is no fear of hell.

Because of the mind giving rise to delight, they then fall into evil destinies.

Attached to desire like a blazing fire, the wise should stay far away.

Those who delight in the five desires, will sink and drown in the three existences,
Always confusing their minds, how can they attain tranquility?
If a person is attached to desires, they will forget the true Dharma,
Seeking those objects, they will quickly go to hell.
These desires are only destructive, like a sharp sword,
If one does not give rise to aversion, later there will only be suffering.
If one creates like this, then it will increase like this,
Not being content with it, always giving rise to distress.
Seeking heavenly bliss, one will be burned by desires,
Not creating the causes of suffering, one will always attain happiness.
The foolish are firmly attached to objects of desire and do not let go,
This is like a flash of lightning, moving for a brief moment.
If a person is greedy for the five desires, continuing without interruption,
That person will be burned by the fire of desire, burning without rest.
The gods, with regard to the objects of desire, give rise to extreme foolishness,
With regard to the wonderful bliss of detachment, they will no longer obtain it.
Apart from liberation there is no bliss, and also no nirvana,
Opposing the objects of desire, therefore one should abandon them.
If dwelling in the realm of desire, the faculties will have no satiation,
Because of their unsatiation, by what means can one attain liberation?
If in the ocean of cyclic existence one is able to give rise to fear,
One should abandon that which is unwholesome, as well as the treacherous difficulties of desire.
The objects of desire have no temporary stopping, like the sun rising and setting,
One should delight in relying on mountains and forests, cultivating meditation and seeking liberation.
Desire is not the Dharma of liberation, the foolish take it as a treasure to play with,
ultimately attain peace and joy.
This desire is not a precious place, it is a wilderness of samsara,
If one delights in and is close to it, one will not be able to escape.
Not fearing sin, that is great ignorance,
Non-wealth is said to be wealth, there is only suffering and no joy.
If a person is far from desire, does not give rise to greed and love,
This is well-abiding, not harmed by the fire of desire.
There is no contentment in desire, that mind is not tranquil,
Associated with greed and love, like fire rising in flames.
The gods, asuras, humans, and non-humans,
Do not give rise to disgust towards desire, all are destroyed by it.
If a person, towards objects of desire, is confused and crazed,
They deceive themselves, and because of this, perish.
All foolish beings, not knowing the characteristics of sin and merit,
Take objects as desire, and always give rise to fondness and delight.
The minds of the devas, pulled by desire, become confused and disordered.
If one delights in the merits of the Buddha, one should leave those objects.
